article.title: &nfsquick;

sect1.title: Usage scenario
sect1.para: This document will help you set up a highly available NFS server. The cluster used to for the highly available NFS storage has the following properties:

listitem.para: Two nodes: &node1; (IP: &subnetI;.1) and &node2; (IP: &subnetI;.2), connected to each other via network.

Two floating, virtual IP addresses (&nfs-vip-hawk; and &nfs-vip-exports;), allowing clients to connect to the service no matter which physical node it is running on. One IP address is used for cluster administration with &hawk2;, the other IP address is used exclusively for the NFS exports.
A shared storage device, used as an SBD fencing mechanism. This avoids split brain scenarios.
Failover of resources from one node to the other if the active host breaks down (active/passive setup).
Local storage on each host. The data is synchronized between the hosts using DRBD on top of LVM.
A file system exported through NFS.

sect1.para: After installing and setting up the basic two-node cluster, and extending it with storage and cluster resources for NFS, you will have a highly available NFS storage server.

sect1.title: Installing a basic two-node cluster
sect1.para: Before you proceed, install and set up a basic two-node cluster. This task is described in &instquick;. The &instquick; describes how to use the ha-cluster-bootstrap package to set up a cluster with minimal effort.

sect1.title: Creating a DRBD device
sect1.para: This section describes how to set up a DRBD device on top of LVM. The configuration of LVM as a back-end of DRBD has some benefits:

listitem.para: Easier setup than with LVM on top of DRBD.
Easier administration in case the LVM disks need to be resized or more disks are added to the volume group.

sect1.para: As the LVM volume group is named nfs, the DRBD resource uses the same name.

sect1.title: Creating cluster resources
sect1.para: The following sections cover the configuration of the required resources for a highly available NFS cluster. The configuration steps use the &crmshell;. The following list shows the necessary cluster resources:

varlistentry.term: DRBD primitive and promotable clone resources

listitem.para: These resources are used to replicate data. The promotable clone resource is switched from and to the Primary and Secondary roles as deemed necessary by the cluster resource manager.
With this resource, Pacemaker ensures that the NFS server daemons are always available.
One or more NFS exports, typically corresponding to the file system.
The following configuration examples assume that &nfs-vip-exports; is the virtual IP address to use for an NFS server which serves clients in the &subnetII;.x/24 subnet.
The service exports data served from /srv/nfs/work.
Into this export directory, the cluster will mount ext3 file systems from the DRBD device /dev/drbd0. This DRBD device sits on top of an LVM logical volume with the name nfs.

sect2.title: DRBD primitive and promotable clone resource
sect2.para: To configure these resources, run the following commands from the &crmshell;: taroth 2018-03-05: ygao, should 'master-max' and 'master-node-max' be replaced with 'promoted-max' and 'promoted-node-max', respectively? apart from that, does the screen below need more changes? - ygao 2018-03-13: the new names are not explicitly promoted in crmsh yet
sect2.screen: &prompt.crm;configure &prompt.crm.conf;primitive drbd_nfs \ ocf:linbit:drbd \ params drbd_resource="nfs" \ op monitor interval="15" role="Master" \ op monitor interval="30" role="Slave" &prompt.crm.conf;ms ms-drbd_nfs drbd_nfs \ meta master-max="1" master-node-max="1" clone-max="2" \ clone-node-max="1" notify="true" &prompt.crm.conf;commit
sect2.para: This will create a Pacemaker promotable clone resource corresponding to the DRBD resource nfs. Pacemaker should now activate your DRBD resource on both nodes and promote it to the master role on one of them.
Check the state of the cluster with the crm status command, or run drbdadm status.

sect2.title: NFS kernel server resource
sect2.para: In the &crmshell;, the resource for the NFS server daemons must be configured as a clone of a systemd resource type.
sect2.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive nfsserver \ systemd:nfs-server \ op monitor interval="30s" &prompt.crm.conf;clone cl-nfsserver nfsserver \ meta interleave=true &prompt.crm.conf;commit
sect2.para: After you have committed this configuration, Pacemaker should start the NFS Kernel server processes on both nodes.

sect2.title: File system resource

listitem.para: Configure the file system type resource as follows (but do not commit this configuration yet):
listitem.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive fs_work \ ocf:heartbeat:Filesystem \ params device=/dev/drbd0 \ directory=/srv/nfs/work \ fstype=ext3 \ op monitor interval="10s"

listitem.para: Combine these resources into a Pacemaker resource group:
Add the following constraints to make sure that the group is started on the same node on which the DRBD promotable clone resource is in the master role:
listitem.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;order o-drbd_before_nfs Mandatory: \ ms-drbd_nfs:promote g-nfs:start &prompt.crm.conf;colocation col-nfs_on_drbd inf: \ g-nfs ms-drbd_nfs:Master

listitem.para: Commit this configuration:

sect2.para: After these changes have been committed, Pacemaker mounts the DRBD device to /srv/nfs/work on the same node. Confirm this with mount (or by looking at /proc/mounts).

sect2.title: NFS export resources
sect2.para: When your DRBD, LVM, and file system resources are working properly, continue with the resources managing your NFS exports. To create highly available NFS export resources, use the exportfs resource type.
To export the /srv/nfs/work directory to clients, use the following primitive:

listitem.para: Create NFS exports with the following commands:
listitem.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive exportfs_work \ ocf:heartbeat:exportfs \ params directory="/srv/nfs/work" \ options="rw,mountpoint" \ clientspec="&nfs-clientspec;" \ wait_for_leasetime_on_stop=true \ fsid=100 \ op monitor interval="30s"

listitem.para: After you have created these resources, append them to the existing g-nfs resource group:

sect2.title: Virtual IP address for NFS exports
sect2.para: The initial installation creates an administrative virtual IP address for &hawk2;. Although you could use this IP address for your NFS exports too, create another one exclusively for NFS exports. This makes it easier to apply security restrictions later. Use the following commands in the &crmshell;:
sect2.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive vip_nfs IPaddr2 \ params ip=&nfs-vip-exports; cidr_netmask=24 \ op monitor interval=10 timeout=20 &prompt.crm.conf;modgroup g-nfs add vip_nfs &prompt.crm.conf;commit

sect1.para: This section outlines how to use the highly available NFS service from an NFS client.
